Re: License #: CB820201295
Dear Ms. Sears:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
1/18/2024. An Exit Conference was held with the agency on 1/24/2024. Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months
after the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
1 of 11 employee records reviewed showed the employee’s annual evaluation due
by 2/11/2023 was completed late on 3/20/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(3) An agency shall document review of the foster
parent/agency agreement with the foster family at least
annually and, when needed, develop a new agreement.
2 of 6 open foster home records reviewed did not show documentation of a foster
parent/agency agreement for the respective foster home’s 2023 annual inspection
and 12/2023 renewal inspection.
2

CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all
the following information:
(c) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children
are interviewed, their last names may not be included in
the report.
1 of 4 special evaluation records reviewed did not consistently show who was the
interviewer or the place of the interview.
Repeat Violation-Cited during the 2023 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/31/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services
worker that has children placed in the home.
2 of 4 special evaluation records reviewed did not show that a copy of the special
evaluation was provided as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2022 Interim inspection, with the corrective
action plan approved on 5/25/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to
the time of the change in placement and the needs that
remain to be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
1 of 3 closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (a) and
(b) as required by the rule.
3

Repeat Violation- Cited during the 2022 Interim inspection, with the corrective
action plan approved on 5/25/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma screening, within
30 calendar days from the date the child entered into an
out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of the last
physical examination.
1 of 8 open foster child records reviewed showed the child’s trauma screening due
by 8/5/2023 was completed late on 1/4/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
3 of 8 open foster child record reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation that the information required by (d)-
(f) was provided to the caregiver related to the child’s 8/1/2023 and 8/28/2023
replacement.
• A second and third record did not show documentation that the information
required by (d)-(f) was provided to the caregiver at the respective child’s
placement.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
4

(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
1 of 2 initial service plans reviewed did not show documentation of (c) as required
by the rule.
Repeat Violation-Cited during the 2023 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/31/2023 and during the 2022 Interim
inspection, with the corrective action plan approved on 5/25/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact.
(4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
siblings who are not placed together except when there
is a court determination that contact is detrimental to
either child.
In 1 of 8 open foster child records reviewed where siblings were split, the record did
not show documentation of a December 2023 sibling visit.
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in independent
living.
1 of 3 open independent living youth records reviewed showed the program
statement was not provided to the youth by or before the youth’s 6/26/2023 date of
placement.
Repeat Violation-Cited during the 2023 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/31/2023 and during the 2022 Interim
inspection, with the corrective action plan approved on 5/25/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living
with a copy of the agency's policies and procedures
required by this rule.
1 of 3 open independent living youth records reviewed showed the policy and
procedures were not provided to the youth by or before the youth’s 6/26/2023 date
of placement.
5

Repeat Violation- Cited during the 2023 Renewal inspection, with the

CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be recorded
within 30 calendar days after placement in independent
living and updated at least once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the
service plan must address the living arrangement for the
child or children, visitation/parenting time with the youth's
biological children or a clear explanation why this is not
possible or appropriate.
1 of 3 open independent living youth records showed the youth's 9/29/203-
12/27/2023 USP was completed 8 days late on 1/5/2024.
Repeat Violation- Cited during the 2023 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/31/2023.
MCL 722.120(3) Confidentiality Investigation, inspection, and
examination of conditions, books, records, and
reports; access by department, bureau of fire services,
or local authorities; records; report; forms;
confidentiality; disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be

examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care and
shall report to the department, when requested, the facts
the department requires with reference to the children upon
forms furnished by the department. Except as otherwise
provided in this subsection and subsection (4), records
regarding children and facts compiled about children and
their parents and relatives are confidential and disclosure of
this information shall be properly safeguarded by the child
care organization, the department, and any other entity in
possession of the information. Records that are confidential
under this section are available to both of the following

In 2 of 4 special evaluations records reviewed the evaluation showed CPS (child
protective services) and or MIC (maltreatment in care) language and showed CPS’s
involvement in the investigation. One of these evaluations listed the MIC worker.
FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using
the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must
be completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date. Note: This FTM may be
combined with the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date. Permanent Ward Service
Plan (PWSP) – within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Semi-annual transition meeting:
Beginning at age 14, semi-annual transition meetings
must occur once every 180-calendar day to discuss a
child’s permanency goal and identify supportive adults.
4 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of an FTM for the child’s 8/30/2023-
11/27/2023 USP.
• A second record did not show documentation of an FTM for the child’s
2/2/2023- 4/24/2023 or 4/25/2023- 7/14/2023 USP. The FTM listed as
5/1/2023 and 7/18/2023 were outside the required time frame. This record
also did not show documentation of the DHS-1105 for the reported 5/1/2023
and 7/18/2023 respective FTM.
• A third record did not show documentation of an FTM for the child’s
5/23/2023-8/20/2023 USP. Nor documentation of an FTM related to the
child’s 8/1/2023 change of placement.
7

• A fourth record did not show documentation of an FTM for the child’s
2/2/2023-2/23/2023 initial service plan. Nor documentation of a DHS-1105 for
a reported 5/22/2023 FTM.
Repeat Violation- Cited during the 2022 Interim inspection, with the corrective
action plan approved on 5/25/2022.
FOM 722-8D Treatment Plans.
Agreement and signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker.
• Supervisor.
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
7 of 24 service plans reviewed (related to 3 of 8 open foster child records reviewed)
did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of the birth mother’s or caregiver’s
signature on the child’s 6/1/2023-8/29/2023 treatment plan. Nor
documentation of the foster care worker’s, supervisor’s or caregiver’s
signature for the child’s 8/30/2023-11/27/2023 USP.
• A second record did not show documentation of the birth parent’s or
caregiver’s signature on the child’s 2/2/2023-4/24/2023, 4/25/2023-7/14/2023
or 7/15/2023-10/6/2023 treatment plan.
• A third record did not show documentation of the foster care worker’s or
supervisor’s signature on the child’s 11/24-2022-2/21/2023 treatment plan.
Nor the birth father’s signature on the child’s 11/24/2022-2/21/2023 or
8/21/2023-11/8/2023 treatment plan.
Repeat Violation- Cited during the 2023 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/31/2023; and during the 2022 Interim
inspection, with the corrective action plan approved on 5/25/22.
FOM 801 C Medical Passport.
8

Initial medical passport:
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date to the following.
Updated Medical Passport:
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child’s current and complete health information.
3 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of medical passport signed by the
birth parent.
• A second record did not show documentation of a February or May 2023
updated medical passport. Nor documentation that the medical passport was
provided the caregiver for the 8/1/2023 change of placement.
• A third record did not show documentation that the caregiver was provided a
copy of the child’s medical passport within 2 weeks of the child’s 1/26/2023
placement.
Repeat Violation- Cited during the 2022 Interim inspection, with the corrective
action plan approved on 5/25/2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
R400.12327(5)(c) Special evaluation:
• The agency was apprised that the indication of a face-to face
contact/interview with the foster worker in the methodology section of the
special evaluation, shall be clarified within the report with the actual
location; and if interviewed by telephone to indicated that.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
ADM 330 Quarterly Progress reports
• The agency is advised placing the quarterly reporting period time frames
on the top of the document and indicating the date of the home visit with
the child and family within the child’s current placement and functioning
section of the quarterly progress report may aid in showing clear
documentation of the accurate reporting period and the date of the
quarterly face to face home visit with the child and family.
9

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted one corrective action plan not related to maltreatment
during the inspection period. The corrective action plan related to the agency’s
2023 Renewal inspection where they received the following rule violations:
• R400.12327(5)(c) Special evaluation.
• R400.12413(1)(c) Medical and dental policy.
• R400.12413 (1) (f) Medical and dental policy
• R400.12418(2)(a) & (b) Development of Service Plans.
• R400.12419(1)(c) Initial Service Plans.
• R400.12502(2) Program Statement.
• R400.12503(3) Policies and Procedures.
• R400.12509(3)(o) Independent Living Record.
• R400.12607 Agency recommendation.
• MISEP 4.22 Child Welfare Information System (Commitment 22)
• MISEP 6.19(c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content (commitment
69)
• FOM 722-8- Case Service Plans-Overview, Types & Timeframes-
Supervisory Approval.
• FOM 722-8 D Treatment Plans-Agreements & Signatures
• FOM 722-8-E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary.
The agency made progress on this corrective action plan; but were not totally
successful as illustrated by the repeat violations cited in this report. The agency
provided documents showing proof of compliance efforts, by way of a power point
training for foster parents and employees on the new foster home rules; a
supervisor tracking spreadsheet used with workers for service plans, family team
meetings, court reports, and medicals and dental due dates. They also provided
samples of supervisor/worker supervision, showing discussions and reminders of
various task discussions and due dates.
Chief Administrator Assessment
10

The chief administrator provided a chief administrator's report dated 1/8/2024,
which was completed per the requirement rule and did not show any specific
areas of concern.
Financial Overview
The agency provided a 2024 annual projected budget and a 2023 Independent
financial audit. A review of the documents did not show any specific areas of
concern.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the chief administrator, the Licensing
Director/supervisor and two supervisors, two foster/adoption workers, one
licensing staff, and one independent living staff was interviewed. The staff
reported positives about the agency’s ability to hire the right persons for the right
jobs, and the agency having supportive staff and supervisors. An area of concern
or need reported related the agency being able to offer more life skill courses and
training for cognitively impaired youths.
The three youths interviewed did not report any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the agency site did not reveal any concerns or safety issues.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one safety alert received on 12/5/2023.
Concern:
No operable smoke detector on each level of occupancy and /or near all sleeping
areas. No operable smoke detector in the home.
Resolution:
The agency provided a new smoke detector to the family that is now installed and
located in the hallway in between the bedrooms. The second smoke detector,
located outside of the kitchen has been installed. The worker verified that both were
in working order during a home visit on 12/6/2023. The agency provided pictures
showing the installed detectors.
Concern:
Cleaning supplies, medications, other dangerous chemicals are accessible to the
child placed in the home.
Resolution:
The agency visited the home on 12/6/2023 and verified that the cleaning supplies
were moved into a cabinet that is located above the refrigerator which is not
accessible to the children in the home. The agency provided pictures showing that
storage.
11

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
